title: Is it possible to conclude that discovered exoplanets have life? - Quora

response.answer_text: Based on the limited data we’ve gathered about the many exoplanets and their star systems…no way. At least, there’s no kind of life that we know of that can survive on those worlds.  Space telescopes like the now-offline Kepler and its successor TESS have found hundreds of exoplanets. That’s awesome and fascinating. But these incredible probes are limited in what data they can gather from basically small amounts of light from a distant star as it is sometimes blocked by the exoplanet. Without trying to sound more knowledgeable about it than I am, TESS and Kepler gather data using five methods, as NASA notes them: Wobbles. Exoplanets, especially the large ones, cause stars to orbit off-kilter due to gravity. That wobbling changes the color of light from the star.Shadows. As an exoplanet crosses a star, the telescope can see the shadow of the transiting body, dimming the star’s light a bit.A photo. A few exoplanets can be identified by a photo. Cover up the star and the glare is removed, revealing the planet’s reflected light.Gravity. Light from the star might be bent by a nearby exoplanet.Micro-wobbles. Similar to wobbles that change a star’s color of light, micro-wobbling measures how an exoplanet affects the star’s position relative to other stars.While these methods can help tell us a lot about an exoplanet’s size and distance, and even the planet’s likely composition or habitability (for Earthly life) based on the size and detectable chemicals (spectroscopy), none of these tools can tell us whether life exists on an exoplanet. Keep in mind the scale of this. Exoplanets are trillions of miles/kilometers away. The planet Mars, also being studied, is only a few million miles away. We have several probes on the Martian surface and have yet to detect whether any life had lived or is living there. So you’re asking a lot from a pair of telescopes.

“Is it possible to conclude that discovered exoplanets have life?” Using words to talk about science involves definitions of those words. Simply being a planet doesn’t mean that planet contains life. We still don’t know if other planets in our solar system might contain life. However, the discovery that other solar systems do have planets is a strong indication that ‘somewhere’, we’ll eventually find other Earth-like planets which do have life. The bad part is that, because such planets are countless light-years away, we might never get close enough to those planets to prove it. Without proof, we can’t ‘conclude’ that discovered exoplanets have life. We can conclude there is an extreme likelihood exoplanets somewhere will have life. However, the mere existence of exoplanets isn’t proof.
